newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish forces kill 27 Kurd rebels in clashes.
newsitem.headline: Turkish forces kill 27 Kurd rebels in clashes.

text.p: Turkish security forces killed 27 Kurdish rebels in clashes coinciding with the 13th anniversary of the outbreak of their separatist insurgency, government officials said on Saturday.
The emergency rule governor's office said in a statement that 26 guerrillas from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) died in fighting in the southeastern province of Diyarbakir.
Clashes ensued after the rebels launched an attack on patrolling security forces, killing three state-sponsored village guards overnight.
In the central Anatolian province of Sivas, a group of PKK guerrillas clashed with security forces after attacking a train bound for the city of Diyarbakir from Istanbul.
One rebel, said to be a senior PKK member, was killed in the fighting on Friday evening, Anatolian news agency said.
The PKK, fighting for self rule in the southeast, began their armed struggle on August 15, 1984. Since then, more than 26,000 people have died in the conflict.
On Friday, armed assailants held up a group of 40 Italian and Belgian tourists in a roadblock in southern Turkey and set fire to their vehicles, according to Anatolian.
No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.
According to the local governor in Antalya province, there were indications that the attackers belonged to the PKK.
